clinical_study.brief_title: Cataract Surgery In Patients With Advanced Age
clinical_study.official_title: Outcomes of Cataract Surgeries in Patients With Advanced Age

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates and compares clinical outcomes of < 85 and ≥ 85 year old patients who underwent cataract surgeries.

detailed_description.textblock:
The medical records of patients who were underwent cataract surgery between January 2014 and October 2017 were investigated retrospectively and patients 65 years and older were recruited. Two groups were made according to age: group1 composed of patients age range between 65 and 85 years and group 2 composed of patients 85 years and older. Gender, presence of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HT), drug use were noted.
The results of best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) converted to LogMar, intraocular pressure (IOP) before and 3 months after operation, biomicroscopic and fundus examinations were investigated.
Additional ocular diseases such as glaucoma, age related macular degeneration (AMD), pseudoexfoliation syndrome, retinopathies and maculopathies related to systemic diseases were noted. Pupil dilation properties were also noted as poor, mid or full pupil dilation.
Cataract surgery techniques such as phacoemulsification, extra- and intracapsular lens extractions, peroperative complications, intracameral drug use were investigated.
these aforementioned outcomes evaluated and compared between groups.

primary_outcome.description: Best corrected visual acuity converted to LogMar
Best corrected visual acuity converted to LogMar

secondary_outcome.description: number of participants who have diabetes mellitus
number of participants who have essential hypertension
number of participants who have a history of acetylsalicylic acid use
number of participants who have a history of oral flomax use

secondary_outcome.measure: presence of age related macular degeneration
secondary_outcome.description: number of participants who have age related macular degeneration
number of participants who have glaucoma
number of participants who have pseudoexfoliation
number of participants who have poor pupil dilation
number of participants who have zonule deficiency

secondary_outcome.measure: Cataract types in patients who underwent cataract surgery
secondary_outcome.description: number of participants who have nuclear, posterior subcapsular, corticonuclear, mature, nigra, traumatic cataract
measurement of effective phacoemulsification time in participants who underwent cataract surgery
participants who had posterior capsule rupture during surgery
number of participants who needed anterior vitrectomy during cataract surgery
number of participants who left aphakic after cataract surgery
number of participants who needed intracameral adrenalin use

arm_group.arm_group_label: Group 1, patients aged 85 years and older
arm_group.description: 75 eyes of 75 patients (39 female, 36 male) Mean age: 86,8 ± 1,8 years
77 eyes of 77 patients (34 female, 43 male) Mean age:73,3 ± 5,2 years

intervention.description: Cataract surgery was performed by using phacoemulsification technique, routinely. But other techniques for instance extra or intracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE, ICCE) techniques were performed when needed. Phacoemulsification technique was performed by 2 experienced surgeon (G.A. and E.C.) under topical anesthesia, thorough limbal incision. Foldable single piece hydrophobic acrylic intraocular lens (IOL) was inserted in the bag. In the presence of complications related to anterior or posterior capsules, 3 pieces IOL was preferred. When ECCE technique was chosen, single piece polymethyl methacrylate IOL was inserted.
intervention.arm_group_label: Group 1, patients aged 85 years and older

study_pop.textblock: patients aged 65 years and older who underwent cataract surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients aged 65 years and older patients who underwent cataract surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients aged below 65 years who underwent cataract surgery

link.description: Sussex Eye Hospital, Brighton, United Kingdom

results_reference.citation: Syam PP, Eleftheriadis H, Casswell AG, Brittain GP, McLeod BK, Liu CS. Clinical outcome following cataract surgery in very elderly patients. Eye (Lond). 2004 Jan;18(1):59-62.
